title: Owner of Supercuts and Regis collapses putting thousands of UK salons and jobs risk
text:

The owner of Supercuts, one of Britain's largest high street salon chains, has collapsed into administration, putting hundreds of jobs at two major outlets at risk.

Regis UK - which runs Supercuts and the Regis brand - has been passed over to consultancy firm Deloitte who will now manage the firm's finances, Sky News said.

The move raises fears for the future of Supercut's 220 UK outlets - which hires more than 1,200 people, and a further 100 Regis outlets.

Supercuts, a hair salon franchise, was founded in San Francisco Bay in 1975, by Geoffrey M. Rappaport and Frank E. Emmett.

The company's first location was in Albany, California. The headquarters are in Minneapolis, Minnesota.

Today, Supercuts is owned by the Regis Corporation, which also owns Regis Salons, Mia & Maxx, MasterCuts, Cost Cutters, SmartStyle, and First Choice Haircutters in the United States and Canada.

Its UK arm is owned and operated by private equity firm Regent, L.P., under a franchise agreement with Regis Corporation.

On Thursday, a Supercuts spokeswoman decline to comment on the chain's financial circumstances.

Mirror Money has contacted Deloitte for a statement.

Today's news comes less than a year after Regis UK announced it was seeking a rescue deal in order to stay afloat.

In October, the firm was looking to slash rents through a company voluntary arrangement (CVA) as it struggled with lower footfall, the apprenticeship levy and higher pension costs.

At the time, Jackie Lang, managing director of Regis UK, said: "This action has been taken to restructure our costs to ultimately enable reinvestment into the business to improve our digital platforms and our expertise in salon. If successful, over 90% of our creditors will be unaffected."
